dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HOMELESS MAN, who from his tatty suit may have been a t broker this time last year, is picking through a bin in Manhattan's deserted night-time financial district.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The Batmobile roars up Wall Street, bashing against the N York Stock Exchange, thumping up and down the Federal Hal steps and finally smashing at high speed into the rear en the famous 'Charging Bull' statue. Two enormous bronze testicles thud onto the Batmobile's bonnet and roll away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

His Ba utility belt features a big water pistol, a firework, a h flask and line of shot glasses. And, inexplicably, a big stapler. The younger cop is desperately fighting the gigg

It worked for the billionaire Bruce Wayne, why not the future billionaire Arthur Bach- Templemead? Will I have to do traffic school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To use the technical medical term - megabloodyshitloads. Either that or I've had a stroke! But fret not, I have a designated driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: JAY, a drunk with a bandaged neck, is ranting away at Art who's paying close attention, genuinely fascinated. Cash sticks out of various pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (high fiving him) Cool...

dialogues.text: Ho wanted to evict me, just 'cause I don't fit her definition of hygiene. Plenty of places to take a shit, toilet's just one of them. Just ask the a-rabs.

dialogues.text: Mother died when I was six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, The Drunk Knight. Your Fairy G- d-lawyer's here. 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought New York's underbelly could be quite such agreeable company. I shall never forget you. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crooks look back at him sulkily. Arthur looks guilty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's attorney ELVERTON DEVERE is leaving with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think your mother will be pleased, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, Elverton - if a chap can't help out a few chums, whatever their station in life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other crooks from the cell are leaving alongside them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur steps into a blaze of paparazzi flashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: (points at A CAMERAMAN) Don't point that shit at me, bitch! I will FUCK YOU UP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur! What will your mother say? Didn't she send you here to get you out of the British papers? Arthur! 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone need a job? My last driver resigned after I filled his limo with squirrels. Preferably sober, clean driving licence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crooks all look unsure. Apart from one....

dialogues.text: Anyone know a good bar?

dialogues.text: Pierre? Arthur Bach-Templemead. Can you squeeze me in for a little snack? Yeah, just me and a couple of mates.

dialogues.text: 1047 feet madam, not allowing for pigeon shit. Okay, let's cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi leads the tourists across the busy road. She has to back to grab a teenager in the headphones, who didn't hea Arthur hurries alongside Naomi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I join your tour please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. It's $15, plus $5 for the free authentic street pretzel. Sorry, my bosses make the prices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur produces his wallet full of high-end credit cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I can't take cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, owe me it. I start on that corner every day on the hour...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as Naomi's reaching the other side, a cabbie, drivin very aggressively, nearly hits her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you big blind jerk! Doesn't your braille windshield work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cabbie's shocked - but laughs and blows Naomi a kiss. smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just generalised criticism of his parents and genitals. (to the tourists) Everyone make it over alive? Excellent. Next we enter Times Square, world famous for New Year's Eve, when a Waterford Crystal Ball descends at eye-poppingly slow speed for the inexplicable entertainment of a million drunk fools. Many people think the square is actually a square, despite blatant evidence otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir? What shape is Times Square?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A circle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? Morons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More tourists laugh this time. Some...

dialogues.speaker: GRUMPY MALE TOURIST
dialogues.text: When do we get the pretzel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon, sir. Soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She checks her watch and leads the party inside a laundro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, next the very Laundromat once used by George Gershwin, Donald Trump... 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi approaches a washing machine just as it ends its cy and makes a loud buzz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Mr Big from Sex and the City and three of the 9-11 terrorists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts unloading the machine of a large man's whites vests, underwear, shirts, all stained red by a baseball c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She transfers the laundry into a tumble dryer and feeds i quarters. Arthur stays close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Welsh poet Dylan Thomas drank himself to death at the Chelsea Hotel half an hour after losing a sock in this very dryer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you abusing this tour to do your errands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you abusing the tour to stalk me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stares at the big tumble dryers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These things are amazing. Have you ever put all your father's clothes on and just got inside one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi looks at him, bemused but intrigued as she heads to door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson's out of the car looking for Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the blazes is that boy? Arthur! 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They emerge into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead, the jewel in Manhattan's crown, the Empire State Building. This iconic symbol of American corporate might was adapted during World War 2 in case of attack from enemy forces. At three minutes' notice the entire structure can retract into the ground like a tortoise's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not possible. I should know, I'm a civil engineer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not being very civil to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some tourists laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building doesn't retract; the ground rises up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. The ground rises up! Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were going to install giant legs so if a plane was flying at the tower it could run away. But where's it going to run?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manhattan's in the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'd have to jump in the Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victory to the Nazis. Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group approaches a pretzel stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, folks, your pretzel awaits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group lines up to get their pretzels. 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I know you from somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you go on Perez Hilton or TMZ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gossip websites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That the internet? Ah, my computer's too old for all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the internet? Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life's too short for all this obsessive upgrading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You consider the internet an upgrade? Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why do people gossip about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, that was a joke. I'm nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur feels a tap on his shoulder. Hobson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late for your mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, this pretzel stand is a watering hole for the crazies. (raises her voice to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soup kitchen's just up and to the left, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson, this is... (reads her badge) Naomi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's with you? 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delighted to meet you, Naomi. Normally one has to go to a bowling alley to meet a woman of your stature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, Grandma's got jokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You aren't the first woman who walks the streets this young man has asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this? Joan Rivers' older bitterer sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My nanny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously. Seriously, who is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My nanny. Well, she started as that, but these days she's more of an all-round enforcer and bodyguard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi looks at her watch and glances to the tourists, che on their pretzels. She starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I have to get out the cattle prod and haul ass. Got another tour starting in eight minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I call you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give my number to grown men with nannies. But as you may not be a grown man, it's 917 476 2030.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manhattan swallows the lovely stranger. 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They cross a huge foyer, passing a big sign reading `TEMPLEMEAD HOLDINGS INC' to the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if this is the one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is just like the Komodo dragon. Everyone else is happy to see one in the zoo and leave it there. You had to own one. Thank goodness that handbag manufacturer was prepared to take the poor lizard away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said he's in London Zoo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is, Arthur. Are you the only one allowed to joke now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reception is manned by GRANT, a too-cool-for-school, youn Aryan beefcake straight out of an Abercrombie & Fitch Arthur and Hobson enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you don't. People work here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Mr Bach-Templemead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Grant. Tell me - which of your parents are you most like? Abercrombie or Fitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't get the joke) I have no connection with that store. My family name is Von Krausehoff. Take a seat please. 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Hobson sit down. Grant picks up a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne? (conspiratorial, flirty) White mid-rise briefs...mmmm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fret, Arthur. This won't take long. Then we'll have ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LARGE OFFICE DOOR opens spookily of its own accord.

dialogues.speaker: VIVIENNE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Come in, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur heads to the door. VIVIENNE BACH-TEMPLEMEAD a formidable, tanned American widow in her sixties, shakes hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I prefer `mother'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. You look more like a Vivienne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne nods to Hobson as the door to her lair shuts. An breeze passes between biological mother and surrogate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office boasts many glass cases full of trophies and framed photos of Vivienne's younger self showjumping and holding trophies aloft. There's one small photo of Vivien Arthur's late father GERALD and Arthur as a toddler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne's engrossed in a document, making notations. Art clearly uncomfortable here, sits in a low sofa before her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) So. How are you, Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite busy. I have a riding boot shoot for Petrie Dressage... 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Vivienne's buried in her work, not listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else...I'm meeting Ivanka Trump for brunch to discuss the environment. She's sending her helicopter to avoid the traffic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne's still not listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crashed my Batmobile into the bronze bull on Wall Street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's still not listening. Has it always been like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...which caused a hole to swallow up the New York Stock Exchange...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's still not listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..the world economy to collapse and the planet to descend into looting and cannibalism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still not listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else? Um...tripped over in the shower this morning. Head split open, found a family of meerkats hiding in there! Hated the thought of the little lads being homeless so I bricked up the remaining half of my brain, popped them back in and Hobson glued my skull back together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still not listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of buying a giant. I think the market's right for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stops. He watches Vivienne. He lets out a huge bel Nothing. A big fart. Nothing. Opera. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really are a shoddy mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne eventually looks up. 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I hear you say you were meeting Ivanka Trump for brunch? That's nice. Right. Today we're going to have a friendly chat. Then a serious talk. And lastly make a timetable. How does all that sound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing. Do you have any vodka?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened, Arthur? You were such a sweet baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still wake up in my own poo occasionally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, that's it for the chat. Time to transition to our talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne hits a remote control. A large wall-mounted scre fills with a changing collage of him drunk, dancing, puki making out with women, beside countless news headlines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This insanity has to end, Arthur. As the delightful coffee-coloured gentleman who runs this country said, `The time has come to set aside childish things.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Hobson set them aside for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is a splendid girl. Her feet are on the ground, she's of fine stock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. That's what this is all about. I'm not marrying Susan. I don't love her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And? You think I spent my marriage to your father skipping through meadows? 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not after you ran him over in the Bentley, no. Susan's boring. She's not funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ditto your father. The aristocracy doesn't marry for `fun', Arthur. It's about stability. Continuity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and sinking your fangs into Susan's father's bank account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Johnson family's considerable equity in a stormy financial period is merely a side issue. Burt is a pillar of the community.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His baby formula was taken off the market in six African countries!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A completely innocent error in places where there's precious little for children to live for anyway. The families all got gift baskets as compensation. That little bump in the road aside, Burt is a devout Christian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, because they're never insane. And where did he get Jesus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt paid his debt to society years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strangled a fireman! Who strangles a fireman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur... 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Vivienne. I've met someone else very lovely who, as far as I know, isn't related to anyone who would kill an unsung hero in cold blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Un-meet her. Arthur, you're the end of our line. We need an heir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I nearly gave you an heir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, give me strength! A Bach- Templemead having a child by a lap dancer called `Mystery'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was just her stage name! To give her more mystery when she...waved her fanny around. Her real name was...what was it again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is 33 this year. Her egg inventory has dropped by 23% since you met her. You risk having no sons, or worse, some pea-brained hunchback who hugs everyone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great! I like hugs! And some of them are really good at math. (heading to the door) You know the `Frog and Toad' books?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you don't. Hobson read them to me while you were off riding horses over stripey poles. They're about fun and friendship, not how many unspasticated tadpoles I can squirt up a rich girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father would turn in his grave to hear this nonsense... 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I won't follow in his footsteps and marry a woman I hate? I think he might climb out of the grave and dance on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne holds up the document she was notating earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My will, which I have updated to designate Grant in reception as the sole beneficiary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't! You're my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Vivienne? Try me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne opens a draw and takes out A HUGE RING BOX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we segue to the timetable part of our meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The liberated lobsters are now living happily at the bott of the London phone box aquarium. Arthur eats lunch alone a huge table, THE BIGGEST DIAMOND RING IN THE WORLD is be him. Hobson brings a plate of vitamins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. The ring your father gave your mother, I recall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling its huge weight) Did he knock her out with it, then drive her to the church in the trunk of his Bentley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Your father was a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's gentlemanly about dying before I knew him? That's just rude. Did he ever love my mother? 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They had their days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah well. At least he doesn't have to wake up every day to a woman with a face like saran wrap stretched over a gargoyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stares at the ring again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Naomi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. I say this with love:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even by modern male standards you're a breathtakingly immature little shit. Coupled with the kind of money you have access to, that's deadly. Susan may not have a four hour stand up routine about the Flatiron Building, but she's a solid girl who will look after you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have you for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes forever. You're Hobson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi answers a giant old cellphone in her modest apartme cooking for her dad, RALPH, a bear of a man slumped in fr of the TV watching CSI. A picture of Naomi and her elderl mother, in hospital, is on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your English stalker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi! What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I've never really understood that question. Are you free tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I'm polishing my yacht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's on the toilet in a bathroom whose walls are enti covered in a photographic mural to make it look like he's sitting at the top of a ski slope, with skis on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a euphemism for something naughty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's a lie. I have a creative writing class. Tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur glances down at the ring box on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a contractual commitment. Friday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A voice-activated toilet paper dispenser spits out a shee

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, I was talking to something else. So. What do you want to do? 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi dishes out the food on cheap plates. It's all a big contrast to Arthur's setting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Movie? Come on, you've got to try harder than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you always wanted to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a first date, Arthur. Not our honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every date will be our honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ewww. Okay, uh, picnic in the park...or dinner with a view. I like views.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's standing at a sink. A list is beside him, readin `Picnic in park, movie, dinner, view.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of food do you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything but guts and mushrooms. Okay, enough questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on. This all helps build up a profile of you before I trick you into my basement. I'd hate to not have your favourite snacks ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turkey Jerky and Pez. Are we done? Just that I.... 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line goes dead. Hobson is standing behind Arthur, the ripped out phone cord in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to get engaged, Arthur. The Komodo dragon can wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The original Delorean from `Back to the Future' putters u Burt Johnson's imposing, tacky mansion. The car stops and gull wing door swings up, revealing an extremely drunk Arthur, clutching a bottle of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN EXTREMELY STIFF, MISERABLE OLD BUTLER answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! Is it June 19th at 7 pm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. It's 8.34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FUCK! We overshot! Time travel can be a real cunt sometimes, don't you think? I'll be right back. See you in an hour and a half ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler doesn't laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and the butler enter the large, paneled study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you care for anything while you wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trampoline and a selection of woodland creatures if that's not too much trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The butler leaves. Arthur gazes around the room, which is filled with antique Christian iconography. The ceiling fa in the shape of a cross. A large, scary Jesus statue, pal outstretched, stares at him from beside a fish tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees a cocktail cabinet. 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhhhh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the cabinet. Nothing but bottles of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bollocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Actually, you couldn't, um....you know... (points to the water) ...turn this into a nice 1990 Romanee Conti, could you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sips the water as if it's wine. Lifts it to Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks out a huge, very old, rusty sword on the wall. Beneath it is a small information plaque.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Genuine Sword of the First Crusade. Excavated Germany, 1972'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around, then reaches up and takes it off. It's V heavy and clanks to the ground, slamming his foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Fucking Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. It's not like you shouted `Arthur Fucking Bach' when they pinned you up. Sorry. Sore subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur lifts the sword again, brandishing and twirling it making the noise of a Star Wars light sabre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel the force, Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swings it in a full arc...CLUNK!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur has decapitated Jesus! Where's the head? The door opens. BURT JOHNSON, a large, imposing man with a tiny crucifix around his neck, fills the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur! 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, er, had a bit of food stuck in my teeth and couldn't find a toothpick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt, unperturbed, takes the sword from Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heck, this sword went through three crusades. Beheaded 1000 moslems. Nothing you can do to harm it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt walks straight past headless Jesus to the water cabi Arthur looks around desperately for the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't, um, have anything stronger, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparkling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur laughs nervously. But Burt's not joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `The drunkard and the glutton shalt come to poverty: and drowsiness shalt clothe a man with rags.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely a glass of sherry at Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt clinks glasses with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peace be with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And also with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Jesus's head! It's sitting on top of one of the blades of the ceiling fan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. Can I be honest with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the real Slim Shady? I knew it! 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My faith teaches me to hate the sin, not the sinner. But with you, I struggle with that belief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt turns away to get a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could switch to Judaism. (glances up at the fan) Bit warm in here. Do you mind if I put the fan on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur turns the fan on a low setting. It rotates slowly, head going around with it. Burt turns away to pour more water. Arthur grabs the moment to speed up the fan again, until it's going fast enough and Jesus's head falls off. Arthur catches it. Arthur gets behind Burt, out of sight temporarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, Arthur. However I feel about you, my daughter loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's a problem, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur reaches out and, unseen by Burt, he reaches out of shot and puts the head back on Jesus's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's knock our heads together and find a way to stop her loving me....Got it! We'll tell her I'm on the sex offenders register....No, I am and she knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joke, sorry. Ah. We'll say I'm gay! I did once dabble actually, so I can tell a plausible story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made love to a guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One Moslem doesn't make a mosque, Burt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made love to a Moslem? 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir, it was Prince Alois of Lichtenstein and he made love to me. The fact that it took three bottles of poppers and a Jacuzzi full of Krug to loosen me up confirmed my heterosexuality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur notices that Jesus's head is on backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt picks up a Bible from his desk and quotes from memor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `If there is a man who lies with a male, they shall surely be put to death.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crikey. Couldn't there just be some kind of on-the-spot fine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt really hammers the table this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will stop this talk and marry - my - fucking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus's head falls off. Arthur peers around. It's nowhere

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh bollocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Arthur and Burt see Jesus's head at the bottom of th fish tank. It floats back up to the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a miracle! He is risen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But SUSAN, Burt's beautiful daughter, enters with her bes friend Erica - who Arthur met whilst at the restaurant th other night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Susan. Erica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt looks from Jesus's head to the sword, figuring it ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to make you wait, Arthur. I was talking to your mother. I hear you have something to ask me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur feels Burt's smiling face - and hating eyes - on h 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VERY PRECISE FRENCH WAITER performs the specials menu w ludicrous elan. Susan is rapt, taking it all very serious

dialogues.speaker: WAITER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: ...the chef has bathed the bass in a parceline of Chilean fennel and finished him with a little gift of kobe beef. Also I have a progressive tasting of Kumamoto oysters en gelee which evolve on the palate, from light and refreshing to complex and spicy. A short story with a twist at the end! Le fin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan chuckles approvingly, knowingly, the twit. She coos with delight and claps in appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have something with less words please? The chef doesn't have to re-cook it, just scrape off the nouns and trim out all that gibberish in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just joshing, Dominic. I'll do the skate in wood ear mushroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent decision. Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bowl of champagne and a spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter leaves, despising Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, did you really have to be so icky to Dominic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I just can't handle the whole specials act. It's not a Shakespearean soliloquy, it's some heated up dead things that aren't on the main menu. 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WINE WAITER slams a bowl and spoon next to Arthur. He p in champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I was grumbling to your mother about how things are with us sometimes. How I'm sure you're trying to drive me away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur slurps his champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um hm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she was explaining that relationships are like property purchases; invest only in high-end stock, avoid anyone 'up-and- coming', then hold onto the property through thick and thin to deliver maximum return! Isn't that darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it possible to buy the house but then rent it out? Sorry, joke. I'm not suggesting pimping you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur sees a very frail, rich old woman dripping in diamonds, passing by on her walking frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. You after our first child is born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. Why can't you learn to laugh at genuinely amusing things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YouTube clips of babies giggling. Dane Cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan. Why are we together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Arthur. And you love me, whatever you think. 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have the same sense of humour. We don't like the same films, food, music. You like horses, I think they're arrogant idiots...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't they say opposites attract?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That depends on the opposites. Racists and the Nation of Islam don't secretly want to 69 each other. Susan, you're beautiful. You're bright. You're fucking loaded. Is there really no one else who could make you happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I had a thing at college. That was serious for a while. But daddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy what? Prayed to Jesus for it not to work out, then shot the bloke behind a meat truck? Because Jesus would consider that cheating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan places her hand on Arthur's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask me, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur takes Susan's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan. You're the only woman...at this table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A waiter tops up Susan's wine. Arthur, now very drunk, ho out his champagne bowl to be refilled. 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not happy, Arthur. Nobody who drinks like you can be happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know? What if the drunker I get the better it is for me? Not everyone who drinks is a poet, Susan. Some of us drink because we're not poets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter arrives with Susan's fish and Arthur's drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A real woman could stop you from drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'd have to be a real big woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask me, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur sinks to his knees. Susan waits...and waits. Arthu has passed out. Susan kicks him awake. He fumbles away in gloom, getting out the ring box and trying to get it on h finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At table level, Susan waits, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: All done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan pulls her hand up, and gazes at the huge, glinting diamond - pushed onto the end of her thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan. Would you marry me? Take the weekend if you want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'll marry you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods imperceptibly at the waiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentleman - the happy couple!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music starts. A congratulatory round of applause. Confett thrown. The whole restaurant cheers. Susan whips out her Blackberry and starts hitting keys. 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica will be the planner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica? She hates me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who I love, she loves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. She always looks like she wants to set fire to my face then put it out with an Uzi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan's phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...thanks, daddy! Sorry, hang on, I have Erica calling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? I only just bloody proposed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's phone rings. The caller I.D reads `Vivienne'. He kills the call and sits, horrified, as the entire restaur celebrates his grim fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the gloom we track past the crushed Batmobile, the Delorean and other famous cars, to find Arthur sitting in KITT from `Knight Rider'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have I done, Kitt? This mistake's up there with Hitler joining his school debating team...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to bed, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur jumps out of his skin. But it's Hobson, standing b the car holding a dressing gown and a mug of cocoa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And stop this self-pitying bibble. You're going to be fabulously rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'd rather be fabulously poor. Some poor people I see look happy. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's either because they're far away or you've just given them money. Arthur, poor people have to work. They stand for hours in the rain, waiting for buses full of other poor people to take them to things called `jobs' which they do all year round to pay for holidays away from those jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't patronise me. I have a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lying drunk on a bale of hay in riding boots being photographed by another pampered prick won't prepare you for the work I mean. And I don't want to see you suffer. Take your fish oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very old Apple Mac sits on a cluttered desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph is in his chair, eating Popeye's Chicken n' Biscuit watching CSI on an old TV with a tiny satellite dish on t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are we getting cable?

dialogues.speaker: NAOMI, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: We have satellite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, that's some bullshit aerial from the 99 cent Store!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a satellite dish!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read the box! It said `No satellite fees to pay because does not receive satellite signals!' That's like saying `Hey - eat this plate of broken glass! It won't make you fat. 'cause IT'S GLASS!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi comes in, looking absolutely beautiful. She checks hair in the mirror. 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better than nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph unplugs the dish. The picture improves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it ain't. Honey, I love you, but you're even cheaper than your mom. And she bought food from yard sales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss her too, daddy. But now she's gone and if I'm going to keep you in grits and Oprah the rest of your life, you live by my rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you live like you're preparing for a war. And you earn a decent salary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? I want to know I can look after you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he do, this English bum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares? He's nice. He's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On CSI, a female body is being unearthed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah and I bet that girl said the same about her date. Honey, stay home. I don't want you ending up like that poor girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bad actress holding her breath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She changes the channel to something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop watching CSI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beep from outside. She kisses him and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's Bentley pulls up at a quiet part of Battery Park 46.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Sorry we drove around so long. Navigation isn't my driver's strong point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a huge ding in one side of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or road awareness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Naomi sit in the back of the car, while Marty checks sports results on his pager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you put this on please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's holding a blindfold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a first date? Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. We're in Battery Park at night. I've met you once - in the company of your nanny. You make a disturbing number of jokes about stalking and basements. My dad already has you down as a mass murderer. And you want me to put on a blindfold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give you my word - if I kill and eat you, you'll never see me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shrugs and puts on the blindfold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur guides Naomi in the dark. She stumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm officially a little worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to pull her blindfold off. 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur removes her blindfold. She's stunned to find herse on a huge blanket under a tree in a clearing lit by numer candles. Before them is spread the most amazing picnic of time. Flowers are everywhere. A log fire burns in a grate Soft music plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you wanted a picnic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pours them glasses of 1928 Krug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, I don't know what to say. It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The picnic fairies. Who liaised with the flower fairies, the candle fairies, the log fire fairies, the hidden sound system fairies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts a silver platter lid to reveal a vast pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the pizza fairies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crack of a twig from somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you take account of the heroin fairies who hang here at night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's nobody there. A cool breeze blows. Naomi shiv Arthur uses a remote to turn the log fire flames up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to keep it simple like this. I'm sick of Michelin-star restaurants. All that embarrassing crap with the specials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Where I normally eat, the special's the one that comes with a free toy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur lifts a grill lid to turn over succulent steaks. 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're rich rich, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `It doesn't remotely matter how much or what you spend it on' rich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur shrugs and swigs champagne, pouring more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craziest thing you ever bought?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I once inadvertently financed a terrorist cell who said they needed 100,000 to open a falafel stall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs. She stops laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my G-d, you're serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the craziest thing you ever told a tour party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I once said the Manhattan we were in was actually a movie set built for `You've got Mail', but that after the film wrapped, everyone moved to the set because there was less crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sudden, very loud, very out-of-date ring tone. Naomi ta out a huge ancient Motorola phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, dad? There's a small Tiffany butter knife about two inches from his hand but it might take him eight months to dismember me with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta go, battery. Love you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ends the call. 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom died last year. For eight months dad ate nothing but Popeye's Chicken n' Biscuits in front of CSI. So I persuaded him to move in with me. Where he eats Popeye's Chicken n' Biscuits in front of CSI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like you're very good to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do? All those years your folks tucked you in, did their best to stop you from eating crap in front of the TV. And then one day, you're the one saying `No, honey, it's bad for you! Go to bed.' Weird, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not relating at all) Yeah. I hate that. (looks at her phone) Nice bit of kitsch. Where did you find that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AT&T store in 1998.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's...You've had it twelve years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a fine phone. Battery life of eleven seconds, which cuts the crap right out of conversations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something weird is happening. The world wobbles impercept as the background drops away. She hasn't noticed yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe these mofos who gotta keep up with the latest bullshit. CDs come along, so out with the vinyl. Vinyl's back in, out with the CDs. I just kept the vinyl. Way cheaper, and I get to be incredibly hip once every 20 years....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. She looks around. And down. 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cutting wide, we see that the picnic was taking place on grass covered platform with a tree planted in it - which being lifted off the ground by a crane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't decide between picnic in the park and dinner with a view. So it's a picnic in the sky! Isn't it ace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole thing is rising higher and higher and higher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it is not ace, you crazy English bastard! This is dangerous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry. Forgot. They said to put these on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls back the blanket to reveal seat belts. He straps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi, it's okay! It's very safe. It's this company called `Aerial Delights'. They specialise in catering unusual events at a height of 180 feet above the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gust of wind blows the structure, which swings. Naomi screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what got you into the walking tours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're seriously making date small talk while this is going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be still. Breathe deep. (strikes a Zen pose) `When you can be calm in the midst of activity, this is the true state of nature': Huanchu Daoeren. 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Lower this freak show to the ground and get me a cab': Naomi Snart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing her something) Taste this truffle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi tastes it. It's clearly delicious. She gazes around the crane swings them out over the Hudson. The view of Manhattan, of the river, of the Statue of Liberty, is min bogglingly gorgeous from up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi bursts out laughing. She sips champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell. Gotta go sometime, right? At least it won't be years of pain like mom. Just a few seconds of screaming and falling with a truffle in my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So anyway. The tours...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Be deep. Breathe still. The tours are a temporary nine year fill-in until I'm drowned in a tsunami of apologies from everyone who failed to recognise my writing genius first time round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you write?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kids' book. I sent a chapter to a childrens' publisher. Sunshine Press'. The rejection letter was the meanest thing I ever read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids can be so cruel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur? We have a problem. 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, don't worry. These crane people know what they're doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that kind of problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur feels a blade at his throat. He looks up to see A JUNKIE, CLEARLY HIGH, standing over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone. And the watch. Hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur hands him his phone and watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um. Out of interest, how did you get up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you talkin' about, dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a sleeping bag and needles behind the tree!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. `Picnic in the sky' followed by `Robbed in the sky'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur get the giggles as the junkie reaches into his poc for his wallet. Naomi gets involuntary giggles too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't funny, you lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The junkie stuffs his face with food, swigs champagne fro the bottle, then walks away. Phew. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The junkie's walking towards the edge, oblivious! Arthur jumps up, causing the platform to wobble scarily. He grab the junkie's arm. The junkie swipes, cutting Arthur's han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OWWW! You don't understand! We're 180 feet up in the sky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You on the same shit as me, yeah? Good stuff, right? 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're not high! Well we are, but only in the literal sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The junkie hurries away again. He's about to walk off the edge. Arthur runs and grabs him. They end up in a messy struggle, the platform rocking badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit the panic button! It's next to the truffle station!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi's panicking, searching desperately. Arthur and the junkie roll over the posh food, right to the edge!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't find it. Over here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! That's the bouquet of world hams!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi finds the truffle station and hits the panic button Down in a Crane Cab an alarm goes off. The driver starts lower the platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi tries to help Arthur as he struggles with the junki but she gets slashed on the ear. She screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the platform lowers, it swings back over the river to land and tips them all into the river!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi and Arthur - his face bruised - are sitting in the both dripping wet. Naomi's ear and Arthur's hand are bandaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had fun tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares at him as if he's utterly crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I'm saying this, but so did I. 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has started to fill with groom's paraphernalia - morning suits, top hats, shoes. Erica is sitting with a h sheaf of wedding admin and brochures. Vivienne, Burt and Susan listen attentively, studying seating plans. It all feels more like a council of war than a wedding preparati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summarising Phase Alpha: formal wear for bridal attendants, groom's attendants, mens' formal wear, St John the Divine all confirmed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR'S lying on a chaise longue, hungover. A TAILOR stretches a tape measure along him as if measuring a corp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there breathing holes in the coffin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case I'm passed out drunk rather than medically dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Thomas. This whole thing's just a joke to Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson brings Arthur a glass of water and two Nurofen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Hobnobs. You are good to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne, irritated, hands Hobson a coffee cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Progress on the reception?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black inked at the Emery Roth Room at the Ritz-Carlton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen lights up with a church graphic. 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A first pass at the guest list. Bride's family and friends:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 3-d layout of the church appears on a laptop. In the mo up, the bride's side of the aisle fills with hundreds of computerised guests, many labelled with famous names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Groom's family and friends:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a fifth of that number pop up on Arthur's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can arrange to screen off the area behind your guests, Arthur. To make it seem less desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur groans and leans over a bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, everyone. that graphic's too colourful and this hangover's a 7.6 on the Richter..the Sickter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's sick. Erica lays out more sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cakes, caterers, floral arrangements, photographer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson reappears, wipes his mouth and takes the bowl. She stands with it accidentally-on-purpose, very close to Vivienne's nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will there be anything else, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You can leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why all this crap now? What's the rush anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wedding is in a month, Arthur. 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A month? I was thinking more sort of ten, fifteen years. Just to really enjoy the anticipation of the big day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gets out his cellphone) Sorry, Dwight D. Bridalshower, Operation Ball and Chain will have to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is walking Naomi along the Hudson, this time in daylight. He stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going to end up in the Hudson again, are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can promise you won't get wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hudson is bare of craft....until, suddenly, a bizarre mini submarine shaped like a dolphin, dives out of the wa in an arc. Arthur and Naomi are laughing inside it - unti they almost collide with a Circle Tour boat full of touri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Naomi are hand in hand, walking along the stre He's a bit drunk, wobbly on his feet, a little morose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, fine. Actually... 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Naomi sees something on the other side of the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur gets a a text from Hobson: `TELL her!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Richey Rich. Want to go somewhere really romantic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a big tacky shop: JACK'S 99 CENT STORE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The space is huge, garish and piled high with countless c household cleaners, candies, foodstuffs and toys. Arthur' fascinated, a tourist in austerity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is 99 cents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yip. A whole penny less than those bourgeois assholes at the Dollar Store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur reads a doll's label.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Warning: This product contains chromium, which may be linked to chronic bronchitis and reproductive hazards."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one was on the news. Everyone else recalled them, the pussies. Not my 99 Cent!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur turns the doll over: a sticker reads `China'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe China's trying to wipe out the west's children one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gazes around in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I love this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd like you to believe it's because I'm a poor girl reduced to buying `Depressed Chef' burgers-in- a-can to Right Said Fred because I don't know where my next paycheck is coming from. But the truth is - bargains get me hot. Got it from ma. Drives my dad crazy. The tour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking west, the ladies' hygiene products. Note that the more natural-sounding the name, e.g. this 'Vermont Breeze' Feminine Spray, the more lethal chemicals it contains. Watch out for the products cunningly labelled to make the dumber consumer think they're getting the real thing: 'Special J', 'Crampbell's Soup', ''Aunt Janina's' Maple-Style Syrup...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur holds a tin with a Coffee Mate-style logo, reading `Friend of Coffee'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store music changes to RICKY MARTIN: `LIVIN' LA VIDA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ah, the music: Dated sounds for lonely people to buy cheap shit to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass AN OLD WOMAN who is going through a stack of identical tins of cheap beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I once watched a woman shoplift an 8-pack of toilet scrubbers down her panty hose to 'Everything I do, I do it for you'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur just stares at Naomi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you staring at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just fascinated. 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're good at fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're good at fascinating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CRASH. The old woman has knocked over all the beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands her a tin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offers her another) This one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking the tin) No. There's less beans in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffs the tin) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares and thinks. Arthur puts the tin to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I think I hear a mouse inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur shakes and sniffs another tin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my G-d. This is a good one. No rodents. Packed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips her a dollar and whispers to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick, before someone gets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi gazes at a different Arthur to the fool who nearly her killed. 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a good one here, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Us in a year's time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER OLD COUPLE push a cart past. THE OLD WOMAN sneeze The old man produces a tissue and gently wipes her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you got ill, I'd care for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man, Phil Collins. Gotta get out when they start playing Phil Collins. Want to see how to get a quarter from a shopping cart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, Susan and Erica - her laptop open - are at dinner Hobson's salting Arthur's soup, then checking the temperature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiger Woods has confirmed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you knew him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is he coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He agreed to daddy's fee. This is going to be the happiest day of my life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Hobson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is she here all the time? 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can bring Erica, I can bring Hobson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's my wedding planner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's my Hobson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson leans into Arthur while tidying his napkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Naomi. That's an order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's giving stunned Naomi a tour of the huge apartmen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reminiscent of a French castle perched 500 feet above New York, the penthouse was known from early days as the `Chateau in the Sky'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads her out onto a second rooftop ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A second ballroom. Obviously. Gotta have a second ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where George Gershwin and the Astors danced to Shep Fields and his Rippling Rhythm Orchestra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs her in a ballroom dance move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, cheap girl. We can be Fred Austere and Stingy Rogers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need one of your collection of bathrooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the telephone box fish tank. See you on the balcony. 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur goes onto the balcony. Naomi's notices a figure sitting in the dark, stifling a cough. Hobson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not like other men, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I realised that as I plunged into the Hudson with a junkie. But I like him. He's fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson fights another little cough. She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know he is. That's the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure Arthur will explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The live version of Simon and Garfunkel's `The 59th Stree Bridge Song (Feelin' Groovy') is playing on speakers. Art and Naomi look out over the view, the park, dark and empt contrast to the cheering and clapping on the recording.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi sips her wine. Arthur throws back a whisky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your kids' book. What was it about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Vlad the Inhaler'. About an asthmatic boy detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it was dumb. `The Boy Whose Heart Escaped'. It was about this kid who wakes up to find his heart has climbed out and is shinning down the drainpipe to freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it. 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rainbow Press said it was too disturbing. But it wasn't literal - there wasn't a kid lying there with a gaping hole in his chest. It was just this cute little heart bouncing up and down shouting `You can't catch me, mofo!'. I'm paraphrasing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he catch the heart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never got that far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur wobbles a little more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like the hooch, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if I'm sad, happy or bored. There's this bit in a book Hobson used to read me as a kid that says it all: `We must stop eating cookies, Frog!' cried Toad, as he ate another.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frog and Toad! I loved Frog and Toad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Frog put the cookies in a box. `There' he said. Now we will not eat any more cookies.' `But we can open the box.' Frog tied some string around the box. `There' he said, `Now we will not eat any more cookies'. `But we can cut the string and open the box'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi lays her head on Arthur's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Frog took the box outside. He shouted in a loud voice, `Hey birds, here are cookies!' Birds came from everywhere. They picked up all the cookies in their beaks and flew away. `

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we have no more cookies to eat' `Excellent!' said Toad, `I am going home now to bake a cake.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Classic addict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They might be about to kiss. But Arthur holds back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was beautiful. It's like you read it yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's blissed out face, lying in bed in the soft light

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frog and Toad stayed on the island all afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson's reading `Frog and Toad' to Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ate wet sandwiches without iced tea. They were two close friends sitting alone together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson closes the book and turns out the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't tell her, Hobson. She isn't the Komodo dragon. She's my toad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're quite sure about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Oh, bollocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi's sitting with Ralph, who's scratching off lottery tickets. 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, honey. What's this teabag even doing here? Couldn't he make it in Lord of the Rings land?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that it matters, but he's a billionaire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have my full permission to marry him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HORSE clears a showjumping barrier. Grant applauds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo, Vivienne! Well done!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's watching, sweating in the sunshine, while Marty Hobson wait in the Bentley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be wary, Grant. She's planning to ride you around the course next. Her last boyfriend broke his ankle jumping that ditch. Had to be destroyed on the spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne canters her horse up to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. What's so urgent that you had to come all the way out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in love. With a woman who isn't exactly who you'd describe as Susan. She's called Naomi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, we've been through this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you at least meet her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What family is she from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Snarts of Detroit. 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, because they're normal. She's a walking tour guide, her dad's a retired car worker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan will generate quality sons, not oil-soaked car monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unbelievable! Why don't you just keep me here, pay a servant to wank me into a bottle once a day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...then inject it all into a field of heiresses and see who farts out a thoroughbred first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need an heir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine! You can have one with Stevey Steroids here! Surely even your uterus has had a face lift by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur storms away towards the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough, Arthur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of your business, J Crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are so ungrateful to your mother. She adores you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. Come back here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can shove your inheritance up your horse's arse! 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur jumps into the car and it pulls away. Vivienne sit shocked on her horse. But then she throws it into a gallo and catches up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself, Arthur. Follow your heart. But do be aware I consider what you've squandered so far an advance on your inheritance. That's about $17 million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you do that? You'd never get it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But you'd spend the rest of your life in court. There's a simple solution to all this. Marry Susan. And cheat with the nobody from Queens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's very drunk, maudlin, sitting opposite Naomi. He' holding his menu upside down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been at the cookies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ate the whole jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realising it's serious) Oh, man. What? What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm engaged. To another Susan. Woman. Engaged to another woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slams her menu down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry I didn't tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? This is bullshit. Who do you think you are? Is this some rich guy thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to tell you! I just... 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi gets up and puts on her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, you just.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Naomi! I didn't mean for it to get to this! I planned to just be your friend but then I started to fall for you and I thought `I can't marry Susan, I might fall for Naomi!' But I thought `No I have to marry Susan or I'll be poor so I won't fall for Naomi' But then I did fall for you! Because you're brainy and funny and gorgeous and too smart to do walking tours. You're too smart, Snart. Smart Snart. There's a 99 cent cereal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, so I went to see Vivienne, and I said `I can't marry Susan, I love Naomi she's my Frog my Toad' I don't know any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're frog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Then she said `Noooo, if you don't marry Susan, I'll make you pay all the inheritance money back even if you can't - ha ha ha'. Okay she didn't laugh but she might as well have, the evil cow. Because it's like all the money ever and they'll put not just me but both of us in prison and your dad, like in Dickens. There'll be ghosts, and Oliver and....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, his mouth flapping like a fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe if I'd spotted this facet of your personality earlier we wouldn't be having this conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads towards the door. Arthur regains his lucidity f moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toad? Stay a bit longer. Please? 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'cause it'll reduce the proportion of my life I'll spend feeling utterly miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi watches him take another big slug of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bea Arthur? What's she got to do with all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
