dialogues.text: She shakes her head and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi's looking very sad, shaking - because she's comfort Ralph, who is sobbing on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be okay. I'll get you a beer, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have to be alone for a minute...Oh, G-d, I can't bear it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur sits miserable, drinking, as he sits beside Susan Dane Cook gig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi's been crying. She's reading the screen of an ancie Apple Mac: `THE BOY WHOSE HEART ESCAPED' by N J Snart. Sh reads a paragraph - and smiles. This stuff isn't so bad. 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Susan are getting a dance lesson from a CHOREOGRAPHER, clicking her fingers to a club anthem vers of the awful Jefferson Starship song. Arthur dances terri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson watches sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi's typing, getting back into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tailor is positioning a top hat on Arthur's miserable head. He's shirtless and unshaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is coming up over Queens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ancient dot matrix printer spits out a final page. Nao is at a desk with A PILE OF FINISHED MANUSCRIPTS and envelopes to various publishers. One is to `Rainbow Press

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi's pointing at the Chrysler Building for a particula grumpy bunch of tourists of all types and ages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Designed by William Van Allen and inspired by the machine age of the 1920s, the Chrysler...

dialogues.speaker: RUDE MALE TOURIST
dialogues.text: Hey. I got a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, interrupt. Hell, who wants to come home with me and butt in with questions while I'm watching Letterman? `Yo. How tall is Dave?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir. Late night, no sleep, long day. What's your question? 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The opening bars of a familiar song start up somewhere, filling the street. Suddenly, some of the members of her group start lip syncing to Phil Collins.

dialogues.speaker: RUDE MALE TOURIST
dialogues.text: How can I just let you walk away, just let you leave without a trace?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I stand here taking every breath with you, ooh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the only one who really knew me at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A van with speakers on the top is parked nearby, pumping the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is going on?

dialogues.speaker: OLD FEMALE TOURIST
dialogues.text: How can you just walk away from me, when all I can do is watch you leave?

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE BOY TOURIST
dialogues.text: 'cause we've shared the laughter and the pain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And even shared the tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Yellow Cab goes by, the driver lip-syncing out the wind

dialogues.speaker: NEWSSTAND GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're the only one who really knew me at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song hits a hard club mix. Arthur bursts from the bac the van in a frog outfit! The `tourists' launch into a we rehearsed dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lip syncing too) So take a look at me now, 'cause there's just an empty space. And there's nothing left here to remind me, just the memory of your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look at me now, `cause there's just an empty space, And you coming back to me is against all odds and that's what I've got to face...Just take a look at me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song builds to a dance crescendo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A magical moment. The crowd watches. How can she say no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to be a wet blanket, folks. he's getting married. But I guess he didn't choreograph that bit for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But..but this took ages to rehearse. I had the frog outfit specially made. These aren't actual tourists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gathered that, Arthur. Are you capable of doing anything without it being a grand gesture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like Hobson said. You're not like other men. If you were normal, if the money and the booze didn't cloud everything, you'd deal with the fact that you're engaged, rather than just looking for ways to win me back. But it was a lovely routine, really. Fantastic outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out his flask and has a swig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to see someone, Arthur. Seriously. 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's in his cuboid David Blaine shower. He picks up h binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson! Female Tom Hanks has had a haircut! Hobson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Marty pipes up on the little inset Hobson screen. He looks at a note in Hobson's handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says here you shouldn't forget to clean your junk. I guess that's what...'genitahlio-ah' is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty? What are you doing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson left me in charge. She's gone to bed. She had a headache.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's had quite a few headaches lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She blacked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson's in bed, watching a Discovery Channel documentary about grizzly bears. Arthur hits pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put my bears back on, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not until you answer my question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson closes her eyes. She hams the next bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm travelling down a white tunnel. To - a garden? Mother? Father? Why is it so hot? Who's the red gentleman with the big pitchfork?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you cut it out? 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. There are three books. This is important. Take them back to the library...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She feigns a melodramatic death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson, please. Don't die any more. It's getting very boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. Old women, like bears, get sore heads. Are you okay? You look a little lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi doesn't want to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A terrible shame she had to go. A little tart like that could have saved you a fortune in prostitutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, old woman. Don't ever talk about Naomi that way again. What gives you the right to be such a snob? You're just...you're just... Mary Poppins with a menopause!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur storms out, slamming the door. But within 10 secon he returns, humbled, ashamed - a regretful naughty child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson, I've never raised my voice to you. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry too. You know, Arthur, you may be growing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be younger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, it's your job to be older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson. If you're feeling better tomorrow, will you accompany me somewhere? 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pats his hand gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty and Hobson are staring, bemused.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: How do I look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's wearing a huge, ludicrous wig and beard. Hobson Marty fight giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't have this getting out. I'm in the public eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it would be disastrous to harm such a dignified profile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks, scared, at the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be okay, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AA MEMBERS are sitting in a circle. MEGAN, a respectable- looking, smart woman, is speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was waking up four, five, six mornings a week in different mens' beds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur (in his ludicrous disguise), Hobson and Marty ente

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to die. To be nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man, JAMES, speaks emotionally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I steal from my friends, my family. I sold my son's pedal car so I could score junk... 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur - utterly depressed - has his head in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I accidentally backed my car over my mother outside Walgreens...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty chuckles. He tries to fist-bump James.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty! This isn't a sports bar in Chicago. These people aren't here to brag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a business, a home and it's all gone! I'm in this fucking grave and they're pouring the earth in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoooaaahh. Okay, cut. I don't know about anyone else, but this isn't exactly killing my thirst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well why did you come...What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gandalf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur thinks. Seriousness - his least favourite thing - upon him. He takes a deep breath. But -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, you're not going to convince me my life isn't fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no offence but if I ran over my mother, I'd be out celebrating. Which is what I plan to do right now. Come on, Hobson. Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur leaves, the door swinging behind him.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (O.S)
dialogues.text: I'm Jane. And I believe I have a dependence on alcohol...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman confessing is Hobson - on Arthur's behalf! 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and because I have done nothing with the astonishing opportunities handed to me, apart from pissing away my inheritance and drinking enough to kill a rhino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, having heard, comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But imagine being me! I once ended up in bed with the daughters of three of the Rolling Stones. But a) I don't remember a thing about it, b) apparently I was sick on two of the women before c) losing control of my bladder on the third. All such fun...until the strangers I pay to be my friends have gone, the fog parts and there's a hole so big, you could pour all the champagne in the world into it and never fill it up. But I've got so much potential, a good heart, I'm a good person, even if I've completely wasted my short, precious life because I somehow convinced myself that happiness is a Komodo dragon, a case of booze and the memory of having once stripped naked to Beethoven for a coachload of German tourists who I met outside the Rainforest Cafe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's done. An awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always the quiet ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car drives through Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stares out of the window, beaten, drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Hobson. Maybe you can go every time I crave a drink? 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson doesn't even crack a smile. Arthur gets out his ph and scrolls - past Naomi's name, to Susan's. He dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan? Look, I know the wedding date is set. But fancy bringing it forward? I just want to get it over with. In a good way. Think about it, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ends the call. Silence. He looks to Hobson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the agony of possibility, Hobson. It just hurts too much to know I could still be with Naomi if I had the guts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just promise you'll never ask me to sleep with Susan for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi's riding the bus. Her phone rings. `Number withheld She rolls her eyes and answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, if that's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Yes. Yes, I did...Yes. Sorry? Really? Well I worked pretty hard on it..Love to...Love to...What time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredibly excited, she grabs a pen and writes on a walki tours brochure: `JULIAN BARBER...RAINBOW PRESS...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call in dead to work. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She writes `TUESDAY 11.30' and an address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a ring at the doorbell. Ralph answers. It's Hobso

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Mr Snart. Is Naomi here? 79.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be the nanny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph embraces her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please stop this, I can't inhale and am in danger of treading on one of your knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph releases her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you and your undershirt would walk two paces back I could enter this dwelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi appears, looking more of a writer than a tour guide

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever since I met Arthur I liked him. We have to make sure these two wonderful kids stay together...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try not to talk. It's not your words but the breath which bears them. Perhaps you could repair to the East Wing and make me a cup of tea? I wish to speak to Naomi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is having a pre-wedding party tonight. You should come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, should I? Are all the other girls he passed up going too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson picks up a letter from Rainbow Press and peruses i 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want to show Arthur how well you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him thanks, but I have a deadline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur doesn't know I'm here. He's far too decent to be involved in something so tawdry. You could bring your father. A magical experience before he's too big to leave this apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I go to this? Why would I do that to myself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, if there's one thing old women can tell, it's young men in love. And the food promises to be breathtakingly free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson has a slight dizzy spell and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better than you, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really look out for Arthur, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And it is a job that I recommend highly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph comes back and with a cup of disgusting-looking tea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really look out for this gentleman, from what I've heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, what am I gonna do? The no-kill pet shelter won't take him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph hands Hobson the cup of tea. 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Would you go the bathroom and commence washing? You only have three hours and it could be quite a project.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph goes. Naomi takes the tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate what you're trying to do but I'm not going to that party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suit yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson gets up, still dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And he has seen me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Arthur has a very good friend. May I kiss you on the cheek?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it something you feel strongly about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Hobson falls back into her chair heavily, looking sic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad! Call 911.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HORDES OF SMARTLY-DRESSED RICH PEOPLE are gathering on Bu Johnson's mansion for the society night of the year. A hi level security presence is much in evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LIVE BAND plays a cheesy soft-rock version of `Addicted Love'. ARISTOCRATS mingle with CRASS NEW MONEY TYPES ming with TIGER WOODS. The band finishes the song. 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. We're going to move things up tempo now with `The Only Thing That Looks Good On Me Is You.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band start playing again. Partygoers hit the dance fl Vivienne, Susan, Burt and Erica pass a huge ice statue of Susan and Arthur in a loving embrace and amazing catering

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Splendid affair, Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't thank me, thank Erica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica shrugs modestly. Arthur appears. Burt puts a big bu arm around him and squeezes him a little too hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi climbs out of a crappy cab. She's on her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Hobson, you're talking out of your frumpy English ass. Arthur needs to know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson's in bed looking ill. Ralph's fussing over her pil Hobson slaps him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not to pull him out of that party on my behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Naomi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Naomi's gone. Ralph tries to plump the pillow again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna get through this, babe. Then who knows what the future may hold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi hurries past A DOOR MAN with a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, madam. Name? Madam? 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi grabs the arm of A MALE GUEST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snart plus one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hurries in with the bemused, but delighted man. The D MAN checks his clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi enters the party, releasing the man, who's disappoi to see her go. She looks around for Arthur, getting admir looks from other men - and women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice dress. Vera Wang?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ross Dress For Less. You know where Arthur is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi moves on. The Door Man appears, looking around for gatecrasher. The man whose arm she took on the way in - h called JUSTIN - is also on the prowl for her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt takes to the stage to applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Arthur proposed to my daughter, I was overjoyous. The Bach-Templemeads are my kind of people: classy. Respectable. Well spoken. People like in Shakespeare in Love, who esprouse the same values I have always upheld both in my business and spiritual life. But tonight isn't about me or America's leading independent formula brand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur takes the stage to wild applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Burt! I've actually prepared a little surprise song with my friends here. 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band starts playing `Close To You' by the Carpenters. Arthur sings to Susan, down in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does cash suddenly appear, every time you are near?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like me, it longs to be, close to Sue. Why do cars fall out of the sky, all of which, I can buy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll sing a proper song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say potayto and I say potahto, You say tomayto and I say tomahto, potayto, potahto, tomayto, tomahto, Let's call the whole thing off! You say AA, and I say `no way', you say `Red Bull' and I say `Go away, Rehab, No way, Red Bull...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUSTIN approaches Naomi, who's still looking around for Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We meet again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Have you seen Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ballroom. I'll take you to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Justin takes Naomi's arm and leads her at a leisurely pac They pass a portrait of Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so happy for Arthur and Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Justin points at a portrait of Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course she is. Why would Arthur marry a pig? 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Door Man appears, seeing Naomi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What business is your family in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm? Oh, I'm the heiress to a fortune built on small pets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hamsters, mice, doglets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doglets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tiny dogs. The technology's not perfect. Seeing a horse the size of a can of soup fall dead before your eyes - that shit stays with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk through a door, ending up in a garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure he's this way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi turns to A WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a WOMAN) Excuse me. Have you seen Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That way. The ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Justin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi hurries away - running straight into the Door Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, madam. You're not an authorized guest. 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. I'm here to give Arthur some very important news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you are. (takes her arm) Shall we discuss this outside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your hands off me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tussle. Arthur intercedes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Jeff. She can stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, can I talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN IN A WHITE COAT is on the phone beside Hobson's bed

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN A WHITE COAT
dialogues.text: We ran tests. It was just a dizzy spell. We'll be sending her home tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about the other blackouts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson snatches the phone from the Man in a White Coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, I'm fine. Do not leave that party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's on the phone, coat on, in a big empty panelled r

dialogues.speaker: HOBSON, (O.S, OFF)
dialogues.text: Especially now that Naomi is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The call ends. Arthur looks across at Naomi, at the other of the room, looking so beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's fine. They're sending her home. Do you want a drink? 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks, Arthur. I should go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you came all this way. There's ridiculously fancy food, there's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. Please. Can you just call me a cab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No laughter this time. It's not funny. He takes out his iPhone again. Stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Hobson usually...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orders cabs to take the girls away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's busted. He scrolls the phone for a cab number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming all this way. I'm sorry for all the stupid presents and calls and gestures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi looks up at a portrait of Burt and young, prissy, b beautiful Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a looker from the get-go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you like as a kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuts. I thought the moon followed me. I would walk and think the moon went any place that I did. I thought it meant something special would happen. So I've been waiting. What an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur sees a sound system. He goes over and plugs his iP into it, then takes Naomi in his arms. 88.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. We've been through this. Call that cab please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur looks down into her eyes and hits `PLAY' on his iPhone. Music starts: it's not a slow, smoochy song but b brassy and upbeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur ballroom dances Naomi at speed around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Bombay, a travelling circus came, they brought an intelligent elephant and Nellie was her name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the bejeezus is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson used to sing it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One dark night, she slipped her iron chain. Off she ran to Hindustan and was never seen again. Nellie the Elephant packed her bags, And said goodbye to the circus, Off she went with a trumpety trump, Trump trump trump...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's energetic, wonderful, as romantic as any slow dance. They stop dancing. Arthur stares at Naomi. At last, they kiss. But the music stops. It's Vivienne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the tour guide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the Vivienne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crowded field, writing. 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe someone will see her potential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all know who's seen her potential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, of course, you don't know, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur suddenly goes pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne, please. Don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son became fond of you. You're not the first. Or the last, I imagine. Anyway I was scanning his monthly expenses - which always makes for entertaining reading, all those gifts for all those girls - and found he'd bought an entire publishing company called...what was it now? Rainbow Press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bought Rainbow press? So you could tell them to publish my book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows people, dear. I'm sure you do too, though the people you know tend not to own books, let alone publishers. Arthur, I trust we'll see you back at the party? Susan's a little worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne leaves. Naomi storms away. Arthur chases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NAOMI! PLEASE! I didn't think I would ever see you again. I was just trying to give you some... 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confidence? Self esteem isn't a gift, Arthur! It isn't a fur coat or a thousand billion orchids or an apartment made from truffles or whatever else you rich freaks use to express love!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur looks incredibly hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do express love! I love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just told me to! And stop going on about me being rich! You think it's easy being trapped by money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi gets her old phone out. She speaks into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Amnesty? Come quick! Arthur's being held against his will in Guantamoney Bay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abu Greed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop riffing with me! How dare you do what you did. I didn't need your money to feel good about myself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Being cheap gives you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least I'm prepared to have fun. To live. I'm not all `Oooh look at me with my antique food, aren't I cool?' And...and...your phone's RUBBISH! It's made of bits of old doorbell and vibrator, I bet you can only get calls from 1994 on it! 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as I don't get any from a drunk, rich fuck up like you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? I heard shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an employee of Arthur's. I came to complain about the conditions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bach-Templemead, I know you thought putting half and half in the staff kitchen was an improvement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But some people prefer Coffee Mate! You were disrespectful. I quit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi walks away, slamming a door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you changed the creamer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, Marty called from the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Hobson's fine. I spoke to her doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson is lying in bed, looking even iller than before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a headache!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop saying that! You bribed a hospital orderly to tell me you were okay! 92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, bothersnaps. What do doctors know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Marty enters with a shopping cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Da dahhhh! I give you the amazing costly, health-giving presents!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur starts to produce gifts for Hobson: jewellery, expensive bath products, perfumes, clothes, a DVD...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Wake up and Smell the Carcass'.. (reads the DVD) `A compilation of the band's most stomach-churning music videos and deathly live performances...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He produces a DARTH VADER HELMET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put this on, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to put it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it on. Or I'll fire you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, or I won't fire you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dons the full face helmet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much did you waste on this poppycock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Marty laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you've decided not to grow up after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sounds like Darth Invader!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Arthur unwraps a very high-end DVD player and TV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Arthur? 93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is dark. Arthur, Hobson and Marty are all on the bed, bathed in blue light from the huge new TV.

dialogues.speaker: VOICEOVER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Stargazer, known for her distinctive white mottled back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a documentary about grizzly bears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...is determined to catch the salmon, despite the treacherous rapids...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOCTOR enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Bach-Templemead? Do you have a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's looking delighted. But the doctor is grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home? That's great news. Isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a short montage of Arthur, now sober, taking care Hobson with Marty's help: Reading to her...Watching anoth bear documentary...Arthur doing silly yoga for Hobson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is quietly cleaning Hobson's room. He stumbles on document. It reads: `THE BOY WHOSE HEART ESCAPED' BY N J SNART. FINAL MANUSCRIPT.' He opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did this get here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might have a brain tumour but you're not a complete veggie burger just yet. Has Naomi been here? 94.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dropped by once or twice. Frightful needy trollop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought she gave up writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's reading the manuscript, bearing Hobson's notatio `Shorten', `Wonderful - do NOT cut!', `Beautiful. I cried

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just trying to spare her outright humiliation while I'm still here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't wear yourself out. You're not going anywhere soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He taps the top of a state-of-the-art heart monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: World's most advanced heart rate monitor. The tiniest problem will alert your own private platoon of paramedics camped out downstairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson takes Arthur's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. I've loved caring for you so much. But you'll never grow up with me around. So either I retire. Or I die. Option 1 involves too much paperwork and blather with having to find somewhere else to live. And no offence to you, dear boy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances at a MASSIVE PILE OF BEAR DOCUMENTARY DVDs be THE WORLD'S BIGGEST TEDDY BEAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but I think we've exhausted the bear-based entertainment. Which leaves option 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur can't fight the tears any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good son, Arthur. You can do anything with your life that you want. Just like I did. 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you spent half of it looking after a spoilt drunk twat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. Sorry Arthur. I'm past my use-by date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Hobson, You don't win this one. I need you to care for me. (holds up a pill) Now take your fish oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, in a chair at the end of the bed, wakes with a st from a dream. He looks across to Hobson, who is very stil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The expensive monitor is dead. He jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: HOBSON
dialogues.text: (hammering the machine) Why the fuck has the stupid thing not gone off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees that the monitor is unplugged. The cord is in Hobson's hand. It's over. Hobson's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur sobs his heart out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a few weeks later. The place is very, very messy. Th place also seems to be heavily splattered with all colors paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPLOTCH! A big lump of red paint thuds into Hobson's gian teddy bear, which is already heavily spattered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's sitting naked, apart from a helmet, in his tiny paintball tank. He's in a blank, drunken daze, firing pai at the teddy. The tank turret rotates. He shoots walls, possessions, furniture. He stops. 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would Frog ever get up again? Or would he just sit in his tank, crying and soiling himself until he died of dehydration because he didn't even have the energy to eat a wet sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks down at an ashes urn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobson! Why are you in there when I need you? (lifts lid off urn)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's rewarded with a face full of ashes. Angrily he spins turret through 360 degrees, firing paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrrrgghhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty comes in - and is hit hard by paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shockingly bad, thanks, Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want to talk about the Cubs game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nahhh. Can I be alone please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty goes. Arthur picks up his phone and scrolls down to Naomi's name. He thinks for a moment, hits `call'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi is shopping. She looks at the phone, sees Arthur's name. She so wants to answer. But doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stands on the balcony. He peers down at Manhattan far below. 97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COUPLE are having sex. A BODY falls past the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The body falls past a window. A huge crash from off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASSERSBY are staring in horror at a yellow cab, its roof caved in, the DRIVER shaking in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tilt up to find Hobson's HUGE teddy BEAR lying on the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's on his phone again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving a message) Naomi? I doubt you'll ever get this, because your voicemail probably consists of a 4000 year old woman who writes the message down in hieroglyphics then loses it down the back of her incontinence loin cloth. Hobson died. Hobson died and I've fallen apart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorbell rings from off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty! Can you get that? Marty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi? Could you get it? Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws the cellphone off the roof. A couple of seconds pass. We hear a very faint howl of pain from whoever it h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur opens the door. It's Vivienne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur! You haven't answered the phone for eight days. Susan's beside herself. What's going on? 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think's going on? Hobson died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bustles in past Arthur. A PLATOON OF MAIDS follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chop chop! You cleany penthouseio! Come on, Arthur. Have to pick yourself up, lad. It's like when Nixon my Great Dane had to be put down. Frightful state for days. But I pulled myself together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're comparing Hobson to...a dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes. A faithful, humble companion who...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I think I'd like you to leave, if that's okay. Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember who pays for this apartment, Arthur. For everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He guides her out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had damn well better be at that wedding, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. If I'm going to drink myself to death I'll need resources. Bye Vivienne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mother!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slams the door. The phone rings again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? I'm sorry? 99.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is sitting in an estate attorney's next to MR FINK a small, dirty man. ATTORNEY MARGARET AHERNE is at a desk opposite them, reading from a will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last will and testament of Jane Hobson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `I leave my life savings to the Tulare Bear Sanctuary, Tulare County, California.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aherne hands Mr Finke A CHECK for $8,864.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll explain the strong smell of bear shit. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aherne opens a tiny envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Arthur Bach Templemead, I leave this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She produces a teabag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To operate kettle, press red button. Milk in refrigerator; that's the big box with the pretty light that comes on when you open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. You're going to be okay. Now it's your turn to look after someone. All my deepest, fondest love, my dearest boy. I'm smiling down at you - or more likely, up at you - forever and ever, H xxxxxxxx.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up on the KETTLE, steam issuing forth from the spou Then a MUG with the teabag in it. The kettle boils. A han pours hot water into the mug. Milk is added. And a drop o vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt and Vivienne are standing outside, greeting GUESTS. 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want you to know, if he doesn't show up for this wedding, I can't know what I'll do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Burt. He's cleaned himself up. He's stopped drinking, he's anxious to get a real job. He's become a responsible citizen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is stalking - drunk but determined - through the crowds. He comes upon a group of tourists standing by a t bus. Naomi's now wearing a headset mic, pointing south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Due to a tragic error in the architect's drawing, the original Statue of Liberty unveiled in 1886 was just seven inches tall. 100,000 New Yorkers rioted, having come expecting to see something more impressive than a garden gnome holding up an ice cream...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur pushes his way through the tourists. He sees her b and headset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on a bus? With a microphone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girl's gotta have a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi. Can you take the next 60 years off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? You're a mess. You look like you...now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I accidentally swallowed three bottles of hand sanitizer. Fascinating story...Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drinking was the only way I could get the courage to come here and say this: I don't need the money. I love the money. But I don't lie awake all night wondering how I'll live without ever seeing it again. I just wonder what it's like to go 24 hours without a steak tartare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi looks unconvinced. Arthur pulls out his wallet and takes out a load of credit cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The American Express Centurion card - you have to spend at least $250,000 a year to keep it, which I blow in a quiet week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops it down a drain. He produces another card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sotheby's `World Elite' Mastercard for art collectors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drops it down drain too. The tourists are enjoying this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And King of all idiotic reckless-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: insanity: the Visa Black Card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This last one he hands to a PASSING HOMELESS MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIN 3487. Daily ATM limit $180,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man runs into the road. As Arthur talks, out of focus see the man hit by a car, but get up and keep going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (producing fancy iPhone) The world's only platinum iPhone. With police radio app.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses it over his shoulder. It lands in the beef juic pan of a Street French Dip stall. A BIGGER CROWD is gathering. Arthur takes off his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alexander Amosu. Vicuna wool, shorn once every three years from the South American camelid - $50,000. 102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws the jacket in a passing cab's window. He takes his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Westmancott trousers, ten months to design, fit and make. $21,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the trousers to a PASSERBY. Off with his watch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wants the watch Neil Armstrong wore to step on the sun!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur flings it in the air. A crazed fight breaks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stands before Naomi in just his underpants and soc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are from The Gap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry about Hobson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step away from the tourists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about the Rainbow Press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. So how did Susan take it that you're not marrying her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't told her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it to you? She's your arch- enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you six? She isn't my enemy. She's the woman you proposed to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't tell her! Today's the biggest day of her life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wedding's today? When? 103.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12. Which is... (looks at his wrist) Where's my watch gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at her watch) It's eight minutes to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too late, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi hands Arthur her phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know her number! It's in my phone's address book in that gloop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Church?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St. John the Divine. Can we please just get me some clothes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St John..Fourth largest church in the world...111th and Amsterdam. It's about four miles. Better hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to go there? Like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the alternative? Jilt Susan at the altar? Can I expect the same treatment when you dump me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi starts herding her tourists onto her bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, folks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi! Susan's dad will... 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. Prove you're not the same pampered little boy who can have what he wants then toss it aside when he's bored. Then we'll talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits in the driving seat and belts up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi! I don't even know the way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5th...right on Broadway...left at Times...Right on 7th...back on Broadway....right on Amsterdam. The church is the big stone pointy thing full of rich people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus door shuts. Naomi drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi stops. Arthur feels for his pockets. Ah shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, can anyone spare... (to the DRIVER) How much to St. John the Divine please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About 15 bucks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the crowd) Can anyone spare $15 please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about tip? You cheapskate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd just stare back. The taxi drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! STOP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur looks at a STREET CLOCK: 11:53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur starts running in his underwear. 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUESTS are taking their pews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur runs along Fifth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is being fussed over by BRIDESMAIDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur runs up Broadway, passing a Watch and Clock store. Every timepiece reads 11:54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt, sitting in a pew, looks at his watch. He looks arou for Arthur then scowls very scarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stops, out of breath. He sees A LINE OF STREET ENTERTAINERS. That gives him an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gather round for the nearly naked Yoga man - YOGI BARE! I give you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur strikes a sequence of silly poses and names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Chicken forgetting birthday'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOURISTS throw money. Arthur grabs it up. He looks up at Times Square digital clock: 11:56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A taxi stops. Arthur throws the money to THE DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far can I go with $1.95 and a Japanese coin with a hole in it? 106.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A block and a half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur jumps in. The cab screeches away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cab halts. Arthur jumps out and starts running again. sees A BUS with `COLUMBUS CIRCLE' in its window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut to people cheering Arthur, hanging on the bus's fr bicycle rack. But the DRIVER sees him and hits the brakes Arthur's flung forwards but gets up and keeps running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees a Subway Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, are there trains down there, like in films?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur runs down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train pulls on to the platform. Arthur leaps aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stands among New Yorkers, none of whom bat an eyel at his appearance. He looks up at the stations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to A MALE PASSENGER) Excuse me. Terribly sorry to bother you, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without looking at him, the guy hands him a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crikey. Thanks. 107.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is ready. She looks to the door. Erica, who is peer out, shakes her head with an `I told you so' look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi's driving her bus up 42nd Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into a headset mic) ...originally a rough neighbourhood. Some say it was called 42nd Street because it wasn't safe to spend more than forty seconds on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few grudging laughs from the tourists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you burst into song, you're off this bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? I want to see St. John the Divine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir, that's not on our route today. Anyway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know if Arthur's gonna make it.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER FEMALE TOURIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should be there for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other tourists agree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says here `ask about your personalised tours'. I want the personalised tour. To St. John the Divine!

dialogues.speaker: ALL OTHER TOURISTS
dialogues.text: So do I! St. John the Divine, St. John the Divine, St. John the... 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur comes bounding out of another station. Clutching h dollar, he sees a bus. He runs aboard, and up to the driv

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! I'm trying to get to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur feels eyes on him. The bus is full of SCHOOL CHILD It's a school bus! They all stare for a beat, then get ou cellphones to report the weirdo in their midst, who runs again and up Broadway, passing a store's line of shopping carts. He starts emptying them of quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A police car rounds the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, unit 6J, we have reports of an indecent exposure on a school bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur jumps in a shopping cart; as the truck passes, he launches forward, grabbing the rear fender!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt gets up, squeezing past TIGER WOODS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's cab pulls up outside the church, surrounded by ONLOOKERS AND PAPARAZZI. Arthur leaps out and fights his through the crowd. People start to recognise the crazed, sweating panting weirdo in underwear. Paparazzi and pedestrians photograph and film him. He runs into the chu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church is packed with THE GREAT, GOOD, RICH AND FAMOU Vivienne sits waiting. Arthur stumbles in at the back. 109.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's trying to inch along the back. But the congregat falls silent, watching him. He stumbles up the aisle, loo up to Jesus, in similar scantily-clad appearance, on a cr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not him. (shows his wrists) Look ma! No holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur slips in a side door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is sitting, sad, Bridesmaids comforting her.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Susan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan turns and is shocked to see Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur? What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan. I can't...I can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads her away from the bridesmaids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl at the party? The one who talked all that rubbish about Coffee Mate? I love her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan slaps Arthur. Hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! We're getting married!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you think I love you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes. What's not to... 110.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, you're upset, you hate me. It's okay. Now I'm sorry, I have to go, or your dad's going to do whatever he did to your boyfriend from college.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy never hurt Alex. He paid her parents to send her away..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HER? You're..a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lesbian. Yes. You may have noticed that daddy is homophobic. He swore he'd disown me if it happened again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...why do you want to marry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur glances across, sees Erica skulking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on. Am I your beard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why else do you think I'd spend more than 30 seconds in your company? You're the perfect cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been pretending to like Dane Cook as well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Wow. Well. Uh... (heads to the door) Thanks for your honesty. I don't feel so bad about calling this off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica steps in his way. 111.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, please. You can drink as much as you like, sneak off to Naomi. We keep the money. We live our lives. Everyone wins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may be a weak, pathetic drunk. But I won't marry a lesbian Dane Cook fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur pushes past Erica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stumbles out on the altar. The CONGREGATION stares taps a mic from the pulpit like a stand up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, St. John the Divine! Anyone in from St. Patrick's? Bialystoker Synagogue? Manhattan Mosque? AA?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi's tour bus screeches up. She hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's still before the congregation, telling a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the first turned to the second horse and said `That dog just spoke'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hateful silence that only 500 angry rich people can muster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The joke being that it's inconsistent that the horses can speak but the dog can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi creeps in at the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wedding's off. The bride has had second thoughts. I can't say I blame her. Would you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't be seeing me again, as I'm going to be poor. I'll be shopping at the 99 Cent Store. Six pork chops for under a dollar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGER WOODS discreetly scribbles `99c Store, chops' on a out Bible page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I'm glad we had this talk. I'll let you get on with the wedding....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge crucifix strikes Arthur hard. Burt, crazed with hatred, drags him by his hair off the altar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt is bashing Arthur's head HARD against a stone font.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, no! Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne bursts in. Followed by Naomi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt! Get off my son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But nothing's going to stop Burt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder than anyone yet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is over Burt, brandishing a Virgin Mary statue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't hurt me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't I? You crushed me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted you to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. You wanted to stop me being a lesbian!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! Shut up you dirty little dyke harlot! 113.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica leaps on Burt, pummelling his face with her fists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want some more, bitch? Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur looks up at Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica, that's enough, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erica stops. Susan kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me? We could have worked something out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi give Arthur a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm joking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church is empty, apart from Arthur and Naomi on the altar. Naomi's trying to remove something from Arthur's n Vivienne is sitting alone in a pew near the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OW! Stop it! Why are you doing that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I hate an infection! Keep still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you keep still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses Naomi passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to do, Arthur?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get a job. I'll model cheap riding boots for people with no horses. You can write books about boys whose lungs have run away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivienne walks up to the altar. 114.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Bach-Templemead has never been poor and we're not about to try that experiment with you, Arthur. That said, you've shown strength of character for once, instead of blubbing on about frogs and friendship. The inheritance is yours. All I ask is, with Hobson gone, you finally start treating me like a mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Vivienne. I can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never earned that title. I wouldn't fake it with Susan. I won't with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. I will withdraw this offer forever. Don't doubt me, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur shakes Vivienne's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care, Viv.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur takes Naomi by the hand and they leave the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur! Arthur! I am serious! If you walk out of that door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gone. Vivienne sits in a pew. For once she looks small, old, alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Naomi step into the daylight, pushing past paparazzi and press. Marty is waiting in the Batmobile, n repaired. 115.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Marty. This isn't mine any more. Fancy joining us for a bowl of Special J?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marty gets out. The three walk away up Amsterdam Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi's typing, sipping `Sprike' (fake Sprite). Beside he a printed manuscript titled `SNART'S FAKE NEW YORK - A Bo guide to the World's Greatest City.' On the computer scre is: `...the 1765 Irish Hair Famine swept through Manhatta rendering every resident bald for a week.'

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: This is outrageous!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's struggling with a very crap, piddly shower. Rath than the glory of Manhattan from his shower-in-the-sky, Arthur just has a bare wall opposite to look out on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Operational heat controls in a shower are a basic human right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hole in a pipe sprays his groin with hot water. He scre

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph and Marty sit watching sports, Marty cheering as th Yankees are losing, Ralph miserable, The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph stands hammering at the bathroom door, holding a package. 116.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Owww! My eyes! I'm blind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph hammers again. The bathroom door opens. Arthur's holding a giant bottle of cheap shampoo. His eyes are bri red, streaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's in this shampoo? Napalm? It sure as hell isn't tea tree oil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph hands him the package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Package for you. With any luck an apartment for you and Lurch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you liked me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may have been seduced by money. It happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naomi appears from the bedroom. She finds Arthur staring a framed photo of Hobson as a beautiful young woman holdi Arthur as a happy, laughing toddler. A note is attached.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading it out) `Can I be your friend at least? Love, Vivienne xxx. P.S. Lunch sometime? P.P.S. The inheritance is yours. It always was.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur looks at Naomi, at Ralph, at Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On balance, I'd go for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at Naomi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were never happy rich, honey. It's only been a month. Be strong. Remember: however hard life gets, love will always find a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off their stares:) What? Can't a girl make a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur steps out of a Bentley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur enters the AA meeting, clutching Hobson's ashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brought her for moral support. But I'll do the talking this time.
